variant.question:
During a training flight at low altitudes, an instructor simulates an engine failure and notices that the student pilot is becoming very nervous and is acting too slowly. Therefore, the instructor takes over the controls. After landing the student pilot feels weak and is over- breathing. 
 The instructor tells him/her to breathe slowly and to talk about the flight because the student pilot is:

options.text: Hyperventilating; speaking aloud and breathing slowly are good countermeasures.
Hyperventilating; speaking aloud helps to increase the oxygen exchange rate and restore normal respiration.
Suffering from hypoxia, but his/her poor performance must be immediately discussed.
Suffering from hypoxia; speaking aloud allows for deeper breaths and helps to restore normal levels of blood CO~2~.

variant.question: During a training flight at low altitudes, an instructor simulates an engine failure and notices that the student pilot is becoming very nervous and is acting too slowly. Therefore, the instructor takes over the controls. After landing the student pilot feels weak and is over-breathing. The instructor tells him/her to breathe slowly and to talk about the flight because the student pilot is...

options.text: hyperventilating: speaking aloud and breathing slowly are good countermeasures.
hyperventilating; speaking aloud helps to increase the oxygen exchange rate and restore normal respiration.
suffering from hypoxia; speaking aloud allows for deeper breaths and helps to restore normal levels of blood C02.
suffering from hypoxia, but his/her poor performance must be immediately discussed.

variant.question: What is "automation complacency"?

options.text: The circumstance where monitoring and cross-checking is reduced because of the belief in the infallibility of the automatic systems.
Automation is now so reliable that the human input is no longer necessary.
No over-ride facility is available on auto-flight selection as there are enough levels of redundancy to cope with any system failure.
The circumstance where the pilot flies the aircraft manually because he is unable to rely on the automatic systems flying the aircraft safely.

variant.question: A flight has landed late and the pilots are in a hurry to make it in time for their take-off slot. The captain decides to do the before take-off checklist from memory instead of referring to the paper. Which kind of error did the captain commit?

options.text: Violation
Lapse
Omission
Rule-based error

variant.question: What is meant by "passive monitoring" in terms of automation complacency?

options.text: A pilot watching what is going on rather than analyzing and constantly checking.
A pilot's concentration on one particular area of the system instead of monitoring the whole system.
A pilot's belief in the fallibility of systems and constantly checking and analyzing the situation.
A pilot knowing where the aircraft has been, where it is now, and where it is going to.

variant.question: What is meant by "passive monitoring" in terms of automation complacency?

options.text: A pilot watching what is going on rather than analyzing and constantly checking.
A pilot knowing where the aircraft has been, where it is now, and where it is going to.
A pilot’s concentration on one particular area of the system instead of monitoring the whole system.
A pilot’s belief in the fallibility of systems and constantly checking and analyzing the situation.

variant.question: A pilot experiences difficulties in controlling the aircraft and consequently omits to monitor the fuel level. This is caused by..

options.text: a lack of attention due to distraction.
both a lack of attention and a lack of alertness.
hypovigilance.
a lack of alertness.

variant.question: Which of the following is an example of mode awareness in automated flight?

options.text: A pilot on approach to a busy aerodrome knows which modes are set on his autopilot and automatic thrust control.
A pilot in descent knows about the drawbacks of individual vertical modes and can therefore select the most appropriate one.
Flying an aeroplane with stall warning and protection systems, the pilot knows that he is able to manually override the system.
Vigilance and situation awareness are the most important modes of awareness that a pilot needs during automated flight.

variant.question: With regard to automation, select the correct statement describing “blinkered attention”.

options.text: A pilot concentrating on a particular aspect of a system instead of monitoring the whole system.
A pilot watching what is happening instead of checking and analyzing systems.
A pilot monitoring where the aircraft has been, is now and is going next.
A pilot believing that the automated systems control the flight better than the pilot, but constantly checking and analyzing them.

variant.question: A captain decides to perform the before take-off checklist by heart instead of referring to appropriate documentation to save time (1). After take-off, the copilot detects that a switch that should have been put ON had been forgotten and remained in the OFF position (2). State which two types of error have been committed by the captain.

options.text: (1) Violation, (2) lapse
(1) Rule-based error, (2) skill-based error
(1) Systematic error, (2) random error
(1) Error of omission, (2) violation

variant.question: A captain starts to work for a new operator. When he encounters an emergency situation, he starts preforming the correct procedure, but later switches to previously learned things. Which expression is used to describe this error?

options.text: Reversion
Random error
Lapse
Violation

variant.question: What is meant by the term ‘complacency’?

options.text: Unjustified self-confidence
To question possible solutions
Physiological effects on pilots because of fear of flying
An agreement between captain and co-pilot due to Crew Resources Management

variant.question: In the context of operating complex and highly automated aircraft, the term ”mode awareness” is used to describe that...

options.text: the pilot should always be aware of the automation mode under which the aircraft is operating and understand the interaction between a mode of automation and a particular phase of flight or pilot input.

the current mode in which the cockpit automation is operating should always be transparent to the pilot, and that the interface allows for pilot interaction, including manual override of the automation.

the pilot should maintain situational awareness as regards the appropriate automation mode required for a particular phase of flight, and the opportunity for manual pilot input to interact with the various modes.
the automation system should provide unambiguous feedback to the pilot in which mode it is operating, including the requirement for specific pilot input depending on the particular phase of flight.

variant.question: The captain of a multi-crew aeroplane believes that his copilot has made a radio call, but the copilot did not. The captain does not ask the copilot whether or not he has made the call. Which kind of error is committed by the captain?

options.text: False mental model
Confirmation bias
Action slip
Routine error

variant.question: An important contributor to human error is a false hypothesis or mistaken assumption. What should a pilot be aware of once he has made a decision?

options.text: The pilot should monitor carefully evidence which contradicts his decision.
The pilot should ensure that he continues to collect evidence confirming his decision.
Once a decision has been made it should be stuck with.
The pilot should ensure that any conflicting information is ignored.

variant.question:
An important contributor to human error is a false hypothesis or mistaken assumption
What should a pilot be aware of once he has made a decision?

options.text: The pilot should monitor carefully evidence which contradicts his decision.
The pilot should ensure that any conflicting information is ignored.
Once a decision has been made it should be stuck with.
The pilot should ensure that he continues to collect evidence confirming his decision.

variant.question: Which type of human error may be triggered if a pilot becomes distracted and does not complete a task or omits a step whilst performing it?

options.text: Lapse
Violation
Mistake
Slip

variant.question:
A system is all the more reliable if it offers good detectability. The latter is the result of:
1) tolerance of the various systems to errors.
2) the sum of the automatic monitoring, detection and warning facilities.
3) the reliability of the Man↔Man and Man↔Machine links.
4) the alerting capability of the Man↔Machine interface.
The combination of correct statements is:
Which of the following statements concerning complacency in an automated work environment is correct? Complacency:

options.text: Leads to overconfidence in automated systems.
Leads to a satisfactory system state.
Helps to react in a timely manner when a system fails.
Enhances the situational awareness.

variant.question: Which of the following persons can be referred to as being complacent?

options.text: A car driver driving on green light, but he is not looking neither to the left nor to the right as he passes the light. It is quite safe to drive on green light.
A car driver driving on red light, but he is looking to both left and right side when slowly passing the crossroads.
A pilot who enjoys his job and feels safe.
A pilot who has flown the same route for many years.

variant.question: Which statement is true about complacency?

options.text: Complacency is a dangerous attitude because it leads to a loss of awareness of danger.
Automatic behaviour is least likely to result in complacency.
Complacency is most likely to occur when practising an activity in which a person has a low level of skill.
Complacency is most likely to occur when flight crew have periods of high workload.

variant.question: On a particular flight, the captain will be pilot flying and the copilot will be pilot monitoring. Before departure, both pilots have their radios tuned to the ground frequency. When they receive their taxi instructions, neither pilot hears the clearance. State who has committed an error.

options.text: Both pilots. While the pilot monitoring was in charge of active communication, also the pilot flying has to listen for instructions via radio.
The copilot, because he failed to closely monitor radio traffic, which was his obligation as the pilot monitoring.
The captain, because it was his responsibility as a commander to make sure his copilot monitored the frequency.
The ground controller, because he issued his clearance at a time where none of the plots were actively listening.
